personk.NAME: ABBOTT, Rufus
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Abbott Given name: Rufus Birth date: 30 January 1784 Birth date variation: 28 January 1784 Birth place: Chester, Hampden, Massachusetts Father: Abbott, Ebenezer Mother: Wright, Anna Spouse: Owen, Anna Marriage date: 17 June 1809 Spouse: Bowen, Eleanor Eliza Marriage date: 11 June 1854 Comments: Rufus was a census taker. He lived in the Nauvoo 3rd Ward on Block 7. He paid taxes on Kimball Lots 55 and 58. He was ordained a deacon on 23 March 1841. Sources: Nauvoo LDS Census, 1842; Lesser Priesthood Census, 1841-1844; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 1:41-44

personk.NAME: ABBOTT, Stephen Joseph
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Abbott Given name: Stephen Middle name: Joseph Birth date: 16 August 1804 Birth place: Providence, Montgomery, Pennsylvania (Hornellsville, Steuben, New York) Father: Abbott, James Mother: Howe (Coray), Phoebe Spouse: Smith, Abigail Marriage date: 1 December 1825 Marriage place: Dansville, Livingston, New York Marriage place variation: Hornellsville, Steuben, New York Death date: 17 (19) October 1843 Death place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Comments: Stephen served as a seventy in Nauvoo from 1841-1842. He was baptized in 1839 in Missouri. He was endowed on 10 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 1:45-48; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 1:7-9.

personk.NAME: ABER, Benjamin
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Aber (Abor) Given name: Benjamin Birth date: 25 April 1790 Birth place: Mendham, Morris, New Jersey Father: Aber, Israel Mother: Freeman, Phebe Spouse: Patten, Hannah Marriage date: 21 December 1845 Comments: Benjamin received his patriarchal blessing on 28 November 1843. He was ordained a high priest on 4 February 1844. He was endowed on 24 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was married to Hannah Patten by Zebedee Coltrin. Sources: Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 175; Temple Committee Place Book, p. 21; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 1:62-63; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 1:10-11.

personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Abernathy (Abernethy) Given name: William Middle name: C. (D.) Birth date: about 1813 (1812) Birth place: Canada Spouse: Lucy
Comments: William was a merchant by trade. He was listed as paying taxes in Hancock County in 1842. In 1850 he was living in Hancock County and had a real wealth of $200.
Source: United States Federal Census, 1840, 1850; Hancock County Taxes, 1842; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: ADAMS, Arza
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Adams Given name: Arza Middle name: Matson Birth date: 22 January 1804 Birth place: Bastard, Leeds, Ontario, Canada Father: Adams, Joshua Mother: Chipman, Elizabeth (Betsy) Spouse: Clark (Clarke), Sabina Marriage date: 23 March 1831 Marriage place: Augusta, Brockville, Leeds, Ontario, Canada Spouse: Olney, Maribah (Marilla, Marcia) Marriage date: 7 March 1857 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Cunningham, Catherine (Katherine) Marriage date: 7 March 1857 (1859) Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Death date: 15 April 1889 Death place: American Fork, Utah, Utah Comments: Arza paid taxes in Hancock County in 1842. The United States Federal Census of 1850 listed him as a carpenter. He served as a police man in Nauvoo. He was a member of the 14th Quorum of the Seventy. He was endowed on 31 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. Source: Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 222; United States Federal Census, 1850; Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 2:131; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 1:117-23; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: ADAMS, Charles Augustus
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Adams Given name: Charles Middle name: Augustus Birth date: 17 August 1824 Birth place: Jaffrey, Cheshire, New Hampshire Father: Adams, Thomas Mother: Sawtell, Sarah Death date: 15 November 1860 Death place: Middletown, Butler, Ohio Comments: Charles was baptized in 1843. He resided in Nauvoo from 1843-1846 and paid taxes in Nauvoo from 1841-1844. He served a mission to New Hampshire in 1844. In 1849 he migrated to Utah. Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Ancestry.com; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 1:18-20.

personk.NAME: ADAMS, James
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Adams Given name: James Birth date: 24 January 1783 Birth place: Simsbury, Hartford, Connecticut Father: Adams, Parmenio Mother: Cloe Spouse: Denton, Harriet Marriage date: about 1807 Marriage place: Hartford County, Connecticut Spouse: Highby, Roxsen Rachel Death date: 11 August 1843 Death place: Springfield, Sangamon, Illinois (Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois) Comments: James was a probate judge in Sangamon County, Illinois. On 10 October 1841, Hyrum Smith gave him a patriarchal blessing, in which he was told that he was from the tribe of Judah. He was endowed on 4 May 1842, one of the first nine men to be endowed in Joseph Smith's store in Nauvoo. Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 1:165-67; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 1:20-41.

personk.NAME: ADAMS, James Marvin
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Adams Given name: James Middle name: Marvin Birth date: 11 May 1806 Birth place: Sandisfield, Berkshire, Massachusetts Father: Adams, James Spouse: Hannah E. Death date: 11 May 1872 Death place: Woodbine, Harrison, Iowa Comments: James was mentioned on the Nauvoo House Ledger. He received his patriarchal blessing on 27 May 1837 from Joseph Smith Sr. He wrote a letter to Joseph Smith Jr. from Andover, Ohio, that contains a list of those who made tithing donations. He later joined the RLDS church. Sources: Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, pp. 176, 462; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 1:177; Black, Early Members of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, 1:16-17.

personk.NAME: AGNEW, Andrew
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Agnew Given name: Andrew Birth date: 1813 Birth place: Niagara County, New York Father: Agnew, George Mother: Sleight, Ester Spouse: Colt, Clarinda Marilla Marriage date: 1843 Death date: 15 May 1882 Death place: Huntsville, Schuyler, Illinois
Comments: In 1850 Andrew was a stone mason in Rushville, Schuyler, Illinois with a real wealth of $800. By 1870 he was a farmer in Birmingham, Schuyler, Illinois. He had a real wealth of $7,500 and a personal wealth of $3,010.
Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Ancestry.com; United States Federal Census, 1850, 1870.

personk.NAME: AGNE, Daniel
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Agne (Agnew) Given name: Daniel Spouse: Julia Ann (Julianna)
Comments: Apparently Daniel struggled to pay for land purchases in cash. It was reported that he possessed no real property. However, he had 10 horses, 8 cattle, 20 clocks, 3 watches, 150 other things for a total of 191 things. The old Barnum home in the Nauvoo 2nd Ward is known as the "Agnew House."
Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

Gender: Male Surname: Ahl Given name: Daniel Birth date: 6 June 1803 Birth place: York, Pennsylvania Spouse: Elizabeth
Comments: In 1850 Daniel was a resident of Pittsburgh, Allegheny, Pennsylvania. By 1860 he was a gentleman living in Ohio, Allegheny, Pennsylvania. He had a real wealth of $8,000 and a personal wealth of $1,000. By 1870 he was a hotel keeper in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania. He had a real wealth of $40,000 and a personal wealth of $1,000.
Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Ancestry.com; United States Federal Census, 1860, 1870.

personk.NAME: ALDEN, Briggs

He and Lydia were married by Zenos Gibbs. He paid Nauvoo city taxes between 1841-1843. He affiliated with the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in 1863. Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 1:283-84; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 1:47-48; Black, Early Members of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, 1:43-44.

He was in the 25th Quorum of the Seventy. Sources: Nauvoo LDS Census, 1842; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 1:316; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: ALLEN, Albern
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Allen Given name: Albern (Alber, Alborn, Alburn) Birth date: 22 May 1802 Birth place: Cornwall, Litchfield, Connecticut Father: Allen, Daniel Mother: Dewey, Clarissa Spouse: Allen, Marcia Marriage date: 1826 Marriage place: in Hartwick, Otsego, New York Spouse: Allen, Sariah Marriage date: about 1827 Spouse: Hoops, Mary Ann Yearsley Marriage date: December 1853 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Morris, Mary Jane Marriage date: 1854 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Hill, Elizabeth Death date: 2 June 1867 Death place: Ogden, Weber, Utah Comments: Albern and Marcia had two children born in Nauvooâ€“1840 and 1843. Albern was ordained a seventy in 1838. He was endowed on 1 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He served in the Mormon Battalion. He resided in the Nauvoo 3rd Ward. personk.NAME: ALLEN, Daniel
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Allen Given name: Daniel Jr. Birth date: 9 December 1804 Birth place: Whitestown, Oneida, New York Father: Allen, Daniel Mother: Stewart, Nancy (Agnes) Spouse: Morris, Mary Ann Marriage date: 6 October 1828 Marriage place: Cayuga County, New York Spouse: Berry, Louisa (Eliza) Jane Marriage date: 22 June 1847 Marriage place: Winter Quarters, Douglas, Nebraska Spouse: Whitley, Sarah Jane Marriage date: 2 July 1854 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Death date: 15 January 1892 Death place: Escalante, Garfield, Utah Comments: By 1845 Daniel had been ordained a seventy and was serving in the 7th Quorum of the Seventy. Gender: Male Surname: Allen Given name: David Middle name: F. Birth date: about 1805 (1806) Spouse: Julia E.
Comments: In 1860 and 1870 he was a farmer in Dacatur, Macon, Illinois. In 1860 he had a real wealth of $17,000 and a personal wealth of $2,200. In 1870 he had a real wealth of $47,000 and a personal wealth of $5,000.
Sources: United States Federal Census, 1860, 1870 Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: ALLEN, Ethan
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Allen Given name: Ethan Birth date: about 1822 (1823) Birth place: New York (Maryland) Spouse: Elizabeth
Comments: From 1850-1870 Ethan was a resident of Quincy, Adams, Illinois. In 1850 he was a merchant with a real wealth of $1,000. In 1860 he was also a merchant with a real wealth of $500. In 1870 he was a flour miller with a real wealth of $3,500.
Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: ALLEN, Hyrum
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Allen Given name: Hyrum (Hiram) Birth date: 6 November 1809 Birth place: Catawba County, North Carolina Father: Allen, James Mother: Lytton, Tabitha Spouse: Cook, Keziah Marriage date: October 1831 Marriage place: Lawrence, Indiana Death date: about 1845
Comments: In 1850 Hyrum was a resident of Richfield, Adams, Illinois.

personk.NAME: ALLEN, Ira
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Allen Given name: Ira Birth date: 1806 (1807, 1808) Birth place: New York Spouse: Margaretta (Marietta, Mary)
Comments: In 1850, 1860, and 1880 Ira was a farmer in Appanoose, Hancock, Illinois. In 1860 he had a real wealth of $4,000 and a personal wealth of $800. In 1870 he was a farmer in Henderson, Illinois with a real wealth of $6,000 and a personal wealth of $1,725. For a brief period he served as a minister of the Church of the United Brethren of Christ in Nauvoo.
Sources: Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 213; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; United States Federal Census, 1850, 1860, 1870, 1880.

personk.NAME: ALLEN, James J.
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Allen Given name: James Middle name: J. Birth date: 1815 Birth place: Indiana Spouse: Abigail
Comments: Among the earliest settlers in Lee County, Iowa, were William and James Allen. They owned land in what was referred to as the "half-breed" territory. The home of James as well as his stable caught fire. The damage to his property was listed as $150.00. In 1850 James was a resident of Sonora, Hancock, Illinois. He had a real wealth of $800.
Sources: United States Federal Census, 1840, p. 202; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; United States Federal Census, 1850.

personk.NAME: ALLEN, John
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Allen Given name: John Birth date: 11 May 1808 Birth place: Plattsburg, Clinton, New York Spouse: Julie M. Death date: 26 July 1887 Death place: Birch Run, Saginaw, Michigan Comments: John was baptized in 1836 in Pennsylvania. He served as a counselor in a bishopric in Columbus, Illinois. He later affiliated with the RLDS church. Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 1:589; Black, Early Members of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, 1:68.

personk.NAME: ALLEN, William
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Allen Given name: William Spouse: McCall, Rachel Marriage date: 19 November 1843 Comments: William and Rachel were married by Robert D. Foster. William was a grocer. The 8 July 1842 Wasp reads, "W. Holdridge opened assortment of Fancy Goods, at the store of Wm. Allen South of the Temple." "Notice is hereby given to all persons having claims against the estate of William Allen, deceased, that the undersigned administrators of the estate of the said deceased has been fixed upon Tuesday, the 20th day of October next for presenting claims against the estate of the said deceased at the probate Justice of the Peace of said county of Hancock at his office in Carthage, in said county." It is reported that at one point William owned 100 watches, 20 horses, 50 carriages, and 50 others items by 1847. Other years showed similar inventories. Sources: Wasp, July 8, 1842; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 2:116.

personk.NAME: ALLEY, George
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Alley Given name: George Birth date: 30 (13) December 1792 Birth place: Lynn, Essex, Massachusetts Father: Alley, Joseph Mother: Batcheller (Batchelder), Hannah Spouse: Symonds, Mary Marriage date: 15 September 1822 Marriage place: Lynn, Essex, Massachusetts Death date: 18 November 1859 Death place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: George was baptized in 1842 by Erastus Snow. He was a member of the 12th Quorum of the Seventy. He was endowed on 3 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. Apparently he resided above Mr. Mill's Tavern on Main Street in Nauvoo. He was a boot and shoemaker. Sources: Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 2: 508; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 2:128-30; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 1:91-92; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: ALLEY, John

personk.NAME: ALLRED, James
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Allred Given name: James Birth date: 22 January 1784 Birth place: Randolph County, North Carolina Father: Allred, William Mother: Thrasher, Elizabeth Spouse: Warren, Elizabeth Marriage date: 14 November 1803 Marriage place: Randolph County, North Carolina Spouse: Davis, Elizabeth Ann Marriage date: 26 December 1844 Marriage place: Henry County, Iowa Death date: 10 January 1876 Death place: Spring City, Sanpete, Utah Comments: James was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion and a street superintendent in Nauvoo in 1841. He was ordained a high priest in Nauvoo. His name appears as a constable on 5 April 1842 in the Joseph Smith Daybook. He was endowed on 12 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was known by his friends as "Father Allred." He was a Utah pioneer in 1851. Sources: Nauvoo House Ledger; Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 3:503; Joseph Smith Daybook, Book B; Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 232, Temple Committee Place Book, Book B, p. 12; Nauvoo Agricultural and Manufacturing Association, 27 February 1841; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 2:185-89; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 1:105-8.

He received his patriarchal blessing on 16 January 1843 from Hyrum Smith. He resided in the Nauvoo 4th Ward. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was a private in the Mormon Battalion. By 1849 he was a resident of Utah. Sources: Hancock County Taxes, 1842; Nauvoo House Workmen's Book, pp. 2, 4; Temple Committee Ledger, Book B, p. 344; Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 69. personk.NAME: AMY, Dustin
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Amy Given name: Dustin Birth date: 24 October 1801 Birth place: Kingston, Addison, Vermont Father: Amy, Heman Mother: Dow, Lucy Spouse: Collingswood, Christiana (Kristiana) Marriage date: 26 February 1855 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Mendenhall, Esther Marriage date: 7 September 1856 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Scott, Leonora Marriage date: 2 November 1863 Marriage place: Pottawattamie County, Iowa Comments: Dustin was in the 11th Quorum of the Seventies. He received his endowment on 23 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a resident of the Nauvoo 5th Ward. He had a tin shop at the corner of Young and Mulholland Street. He was involved in the Nauvoo Battle in September 1846. He served as an Assistant Commissary Officer in the First Company. In 1850 he was a resident of Pottawattamie, Iowa. By 1860 he was residing in the Salt Lake 13th Ward. Sources: Temple Committee Ledger; United States Federal Census, 1850, 1860; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 407; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 2:315; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:126-28; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Anderson Given name: William Jr. Birth date: 29 March 1809 Birth place: Lewiston, Lincoln, Maine Father: Anderson, William Mother: Morrell, Mary Joy Spouse: Stewart, Emeline Tilton Marriage date: 6 September 1831 Marriage place: Maine Death date: 12 September 1846 Death place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Comments: William resided for a time in Henderson County, Illinois. He received his partriarchal blessing in October 1841 from Hyrum Smith. He was in the 6th Quorum of the Seventy. He was killed in the Battle of Nauvoo. At one point he owned 10 cattle and 40 other things, for a total of 50 things. He assisted on the temple frame and raise the timber for the Temple. He was endowed on 19 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He resided in the Nauvoo 5th Ward. personk.NAME: ARMSTRONG, Joshua
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Armstrong Given name: Joshua Spouse: Kempton, Mary Marriage date: 29 May 1845

He was a tailor in England before immigrated to America. He became a member of the Nauvoo Tailor's Association. He was in the 16th Quorum of the Seventy. personk.NAME: AVERY, Daniel
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Avery Given name: Daniel Birth date: 1 July 1798 Birth place: Oswego County, New York Father: Avery, Daniel Mother: Sargent, Sarah (Sally) Alice Dean Spouse: Adams, Margaret Marriage date: about 1820 Comments: Daniel was endowed on 17 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He worked in the Nauvoo Temple carpenter shop. He and his son Philander were kidnaped by Levi Williams of Warsaw, Illinois. He is described as being "5 feet 11 inches tall, a stout athletic man with dark complection, dark skin, dark eyes, heavy beard, hair partially gray, nose of acquiline form, slow spoken, farmer, and a resident of Nauvoo." He was 44 years of age at the time of this description on 16 June 1842. He was rejected for membership in the Masonic Lodge in Nauvoo. He served a mission to disabuse the public mind over the arrest of Joseph Smith. Source: United States Federal Census, 1840, p. 200; Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 231; Masonic Proceedings, p. 38; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book A, p. 148; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book B, p. 148; Temple Carpenter Shop Account Book, pp. 30, 33, 41, 50; Temple Commitee Ledger, Book A, p. 175; Temple Commitee Ledger, Book B, pp. 224, 342; Temple Commitee Ledger, Book C, pp. 117, 118, 122; Temple Commitee Ledger, Book D, p. 7; Nauvoo Place Book, p. 53; Nauvoo Carpenter Time Book, Book C; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 2:843-44; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 1:178-79.

personk.NAME: BABBITT, Almon Whiting
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Babbitt Given name: Almon Middle name: Whiting Birth date: 9 (29, 1) October 1812 (1813) Birth place: Cheshire, Berkshire, Massachusetts Father: Babbitt, Ira Mother: Crosier (Crasier), Nancy Spouse: Johnson, Julia Ann Marriage date: 23 November 1833 (1834) Marriage place: Kirtland, Geauga, Ohio Spouse: Johnson, Delcena (Didamia) Marriage date: 24 January 1846 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Death date: 24 October 1855 ( 7 September 1856) Death place: Nebraska Comments: Almon was an attorney and counselor-at-law. He was in Quincy in 1839, in Kirtland in 1840. He became president of the Kirtland Stake in 1841. He was disfellowshiped and reinstated into the Church on several occasions. He served as the presiding elder in Ramus in 1843. The History of the Church records that on "20 June 1844: sent orders to Captain Almon W. Babbitt, commander of the company at Ramus, to come immediately with his company to Nauvoo . . . refused to come, and said it was a foolish move . . . Uncle John Smith [stepped in] company immediately threw the command upon Uriah H. Yager. Almon performed marriages in Nauvoo from 1841-1844. He came to Utah in 1848. He left for Washington, D.C. as a part of the "memorial for Statehood" delegation in 1849. He was killed by Indians while crossing the Plains. Sources: Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 4, May-June 1844; Smith, History of the Church, 6:515; Temple Carpenter Shop Account Book, pp. 53, 55; Hancock County Taxes, 1850; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 487; Temple Committee Ledger, Book C, p. 554; Temple Committee Ledger, Book D, pp. 15, 398; Temple Committee Place Book, p. 64; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 3: 1-5; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: BACKENSTOS, Jacob B.
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Backenstos Given name: Jacob Middle name: B. Birth date: 8 October 1811 Birth place: Hanover, Dauphin, Pennsylvania Father: Backenstos, Jacob Mother: Theis, Margretha Spouse: Lee, Sarah T. Marriage date: 15 December 1836 Marriage place: Sangamon County, Illinois Death date: 26 September 1857 Death place: Oregon
Comments: Jacob served as a sheriff and a county clerk of the Grand Jury in Carthage, Hancock, Illinois. He bought 100 acres of public lands in 1836. He was also a merchant in Carthage. He served in the Nauvoo Legion in June 1841. He was captain of a riflemen unit in the Mexican War. He was wounded on 13 September 1847 in Chapultepec, Mexico. He died in Oregon a prosperous and highly respected citizen. He was eulogized with these words: "Took a noble standing defending the Saints in 1846."
Sources: United States Army Register, 1789-1903, vol. 3; Temple Committee Ledger, Book D, p. 21; Temple Committee Place Book, p. 117; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: BARLOW, Israel
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Barlow Given name: Israel Birth date: 13 September 1806 Birth place: Granville, Hampden, Massachusetts Father: Barlow, Jonathan Mother: Gillett, Annis Spouse: Haven, Elizabeth Marriage date: 23 February 1840 Marriage place: Quincy, Adams, Illinois Spouse: Barton, Elizabeth Marriage date: 28 January 1846 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Heap, Lucy Catherine Marriage date: 2 December 1855 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Dalrymple, Cordelia Maria Marriage date: 27 May 1865 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Death date: 1 November 1883 Death place: Bountiful, Davis, Utah Comments: Israel accompanied David W. Rogers in exploring the land of Commerce in February 1839. By 1840 he was residing in Hancock County, Illinois. He eventually resided in the Nauvoo 3rd Ward before becoming bishop of the Nauvoo 5th Ward in 1844. He was endowed on 16 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a member of the Nauvoo Agricultural and Manufacturing Association. In 1850 he was a nurseyman in Davis County, Utah. Sources: United States Federal Census, 1840, pp. 160. 201; United States Federal Census, 1850; Nauvoo LDS Census, 1842; "Law of the Lord" and Consecrations Accounts, p. 63;Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 210; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 3:562-68; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 1:238-40; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

He resided in the Nauvoo 3rd Ward. He was one of the first policemen in Nauvoo. He lost sight in both of his eyes late in life due to a blasting accident. He was a member of the 6th Quorum of the Seventy and a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. Sources: Ancestry.com; Nauvoo LDS Census, 1842; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 3:602; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Barnum Given name: Charles Middle name: David Birth date: 11 August 1809 Birth place: Sharon, Litchfield, Connecticut Father: Barnum, Thomas Steven Mother: Gay, Margaret Spouse: Thorn, Elizabeth Marriage date: 25 January 1831 Marriage place: of Cairo, Greene, New York Death date: 6 September 1846 Death place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Comments: Charles was a member of the 19th Quorum of the Seventy. personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Bartlett Given name: Bryant Birth date: about 1817 Birth place: New York Spouse: Louisa M.
Comments: In 1850, 1860, and 1870 Bryant was residing in Hancock County, Illinois. By 1870 he was a real estate agent and had accumulated $20,000 in real wealth and $2,000 in personal wealth. By 1880 he was residing in Madison, Clark County, Missouri, and was a farmer and a politician. He was also a grocer, dry goods merchant, and dealer in "dry country produce."

personk.NAME: BEACH, Rufus
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Beach Given name: Rufus Birth date: 8 May 1795 Birth place: Roxbury, Litchfield, Connecticut Father: Beach, John Mother: Cole, Sarah (Sally) Spouse: Cynthia Marriage date: March 1815 Spouse: Abner (Aber), Mary Catherine Marriage date: about 1820 Marriage place: of Roxbury, Litchfield, Connecticut Spouse: Gibbs, Laura Ann Marriage date: 16 September 1833 Marriage place: Batavia, Genessee, New York Spouse: Fosdick, Elizabeth Jane Marriage date: 21 January 1846 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Williams, Harriet Cordelia Marriage date: 1846 Marriage place: Douglas County, Nebraska Death date: 1850 Death place: California Comments: Rufus was endowed on 31 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He owned a tavern. Rufus and Cynthia filed for divorce on 14 October 1846 because Cynthia claimed that he had eloped with Catharine Abel "last September" of 1845. Rufus volunteered to go to Oregon and explore. He was a member of the 8th, 13th, and 27th Quorum of the Seventy. In 1850 Cynthia Beach had a real wealth of $4,000 and was living with the family of Patrick Henry Cowen, a lawyer. Sources: Temple Committee Carpenter Time, Book C; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 41; Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 182; Ancestral File; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 4:383-85; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 1:302; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

He had a real wealth of $625. In 1860 he was a wine grower in Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois. He had a real wealth of $1,500 and a personal wealth of $150. personk.NAME: BENNETT, Samuel
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Bennett Given name: Samuel Birth date: about 1809 Birth place: England Spouse: Selina Marriage date: about 1836 Marriage place: Pennsylvania Death date: after 1880 Comments: Samuel served as a branch president in Cleveland, Ohio in 1840. Later he resided in the Nauvoo 4th Ward. He was a surgeon and a major in the Nauvoo Legion. Samuel was an alderman, a market inspector, and an associate justice in the municipal court in Nauvoo. By 1870 he was a barometer manufacturer in Cleveland, Ohio. Sources: Ancestry.com (Peter Schueler); United States Federal Census, 1870. personk.NAME: BLACK, George
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Black Given name: George Birth date: 6 May 1823 Birth place: Lisburn, Antrim, Ireland Father: Black, William Mother: Johnston, Jane Spouse: Jackaway, Susannah Marriage date: early 1849 Marriage place:St. Louis, St. Louis, Missouri Sealed: 5 Apr 1850 Place Sealed: Salt Lake City, Utah Territory Spouse: Mary Ann McEwan Donnelly Marriage date: 2 Nov 1857 Marriage place:Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Death date: 13 Nov 1872 Death place:Kanosh, Millard, Utah Burial date:16 Nov 1872 Burial place:Kanosh, Millard, Utah Comments: Baptized by William Clayton in 1839. Family lived in Augusta, Iowa from about 1840-1845. Rowed Joseph Smith across the Mississippi to safety. Nauvoo Seventy. Endowed 6 Jan 1846. Battle of Nauvoo involved family on Mulholland Street in front of their house. Worked on river boats from Nauvoo to New Orleans to Council Bluffs. To SLC by fall 1849 with '49ers company. Elected first bishop in Spring City, San Pete, Utah. Was mechanically inclined, was familiar with all kinds of machinery, was a musician and choir leader. Sources: FamilySearch; Ancestral File; Temple Committee Carpenter Time, Book C; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 221; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 190; Nauvoo City Treasury, p. 168; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc. The Quest for Peace by Evan and Grace Croft Pp. 274-275. Life Story of Missionary Experiences of Edward L. Black. Marriage date: 21 March 1868 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Olsen, Anna Sophia Death date: 25 June 1884 Death place: Oakley, Cassia, Idaho Comments: Ariah was endowed on 25 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a member of the 30th Quorum of the Seventy. George Cannon and Ariah worked together to make the plaster casts of the faces and heads of the Prophet Joseph and his brother Hyrum when they were being prepared for their funerals. Ariah was a printer in Nauvoo from 1843 to 1846. He left Nauvoo after issuing the last edition of the Times and Seasons on 15 February 1846. Sources: David D. personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Brown Given name: James Middle name: Stephens Birth date: 30 (9) September 1801 Birth place: Yadkin, Rowan, North Carolina Father: Brown, James Mother: Emerson, Mary Williams (Wilson) Spouse: Stephens, Martha Marriage date: 2 March 1823 Marriage place: Rowan County, North Carolina Spouse: Fouts, Susan Marriage date: 25 January 1841 Marriage place: Adams County, Illinois Spouse: Rapier (Roper), Esther Marriage date: 20 November 1842 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Steadwell, Sarah Marriage date: 10 January 1845 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Wood, Sally Spouse: McReee, Mary Black Marriage date: 16 July 1846 Marriage place: Council Bluffs, Pottawattamie, Iowa Spouse: Abbott, Phebe Abigail Marriage date: 17 October 1850 Marriage place: Ogden, Weber, Utah Spouse: Robella (Corno), Cecilia (Cecelia Henrietta) Marriage date: 26 December 1854 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Wollerton, Mary Marriage date: 7 February 1855 Spouse: Shupe, Darutha Catherine Marriage date: 17 February 1856 Spouse: Mitchell, Lovina Marriage date: 7 September 1856 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Wood, Harriet Marriage date: 17 September 1859 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Mitchell, Marie Marriage date: 22 September 1861 Death date: 30 September 1863 Death place: Ogden, Weber, Utah Comments: James and Esther Rapier were married by Stephen Abbott. He was a member of the 19th Quorum of the Seventy and a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was endowed on 22 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. James was a captain in Company C of the Mormon Battalion, and founder of the city of Ogden in Utah. He also performed at least one marriage and was an elder. personk.NAME: BULLOCK, Thomas
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Bullock Given name: Thomas Birth date: 23 December 1816 Birth place: Leek, Staffordshire, England Father: Bullock, Thomas Mother: Hall, Mary Spouse: Rushton, Henrietta Marriage date: 25 June 1838 Marriage place: Leek, Staffordshire, England Spouse: Clayton, Lucy Caroline Marriage date: 23 January 1843 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Howard, Betsy Prudence Marriage date: 9 December 1852 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Death date: 10 February 1885 Death place: Coalville, Summit, Utah Comments: Thomas served in the 6th, 17th, and 27th Quorum of the Seventies. He was the deputy to Elder Willard Richards and served as a city recorder in Nauvoo. He was the clerk of the Municipal Court. He was endowed on 20 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was sick during the September 1846 Battle of Nauvoo. He was in the 1847 pioneer company. personk.NAME: CAHOON, Andrew
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Cahoon Given name: Andrew Birth date: 4 August 1824 Birth place: Harpersfield, Ashtabula, Ohio Father: Cahoon, Reynolds Mother: Stiles, Thirza Spouse: Carruth, Mary Barr Marriage date: 9 November 1847 Marriage place: Birkenhead, Scotland Spouse: Carruth, Margaret (Janet) Barr Marriage date: 16 (17) July 1848 Marriage place: near Chimney Rock, en route to Utah Death date: 14 December 1900 Death place: Murray, Salt Lake, Utah Burial place: Murray, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: Andrew was a member of the Nauvoo Brass Band and a full-time stonecutter on the Nauvoo Temple. He was a member of the 36th Quorum of the Seventy. He was endowed on 10 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. In 1850 he was a stonecutter by trade with $500.00 in real wealth. In 1870 he was a farmer with $5,000.00 in real wealth. In1880 he was a farmer in South Cottonwood, Utah. Sources: Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 4:443; William Clayton Memorandum, 31 May 1845, p. 94; Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, p.196; Temple Committee Carpenter Time, Book C; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 8:180-84; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: CAHOON, Daniel S.
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Cahoon Given name: Daniel Middle name: Stiles Birth date: 7 April 1822 Birth place: Kirtland, Geauga, Ohio Father: Cahoon, Reynolds Mother: Stiles, Thirza Spouse: Spencer, Jane Amanda Marriage date: 27 July 1843 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Spencer, Martha Ellen Marriage date: 1847 Marriage place: Pottawattamie County, Iowa Comments: Daniel and Jane were married by Elder Willard Richards in Nauvoo. Daniel was a full-time stonecutter on the Nauvoo Temple. He cut the stone for the baptismal font in the Nauvoo Temple. He was ordained to the 2nd Quorum of the Seventy and endowed in Nauvoo on 24 December 1845. Sources: Temple Committee Carpenter Time, Book C; Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 4:450; Temple Committee Ledger, Book B, pp. 28, 283; Nauvoo Marriages, p.14; Hancock County Marriages, p. 67; William Clayton Memorandum, 31 May 1845, p. 94; Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, p. 54; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Early Members of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, 8:185-89; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: CAHOON, Pulaski S.
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Cahoon Given name: Pulaski (Puliski) Middle name: Stephen Birth date: 18 September 1820 Birth date variant: 20 September 1820 Birth place: Harpersfield, Ashtabula, Ohio Father: Cahoon, Reynolds Mother: Stiles, Thira (Thirza) Spouse: Leopold, Louisa Marriage date: 9 February 1840 Marriage place: Quincy, Adams, Illinois Death date: 15 February 1892 Death place: LaGrange, Lewis, Missouri Comments: Pulaski resided in the Nauvoo 5th Ward. On 30 October 1841 the Nauvoo Legion was called out to remove "a grog shop kept by Pulaski S. Cahoon. It was declared a nuisance by the city council." Pulaski was a stonecutter on the Nauvoo Temple. He was ordained a seventy and endowed on 28 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. In 1850 he was a stonecutter in South Cottonwood, Utah. He was also an auctioneer and a grocer. Sources: Smith, History of the Church, 4:442; Nauvoo Merchant License Tax, p.4; Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, pp. 10, 11, 97; Temple Committee Ledger, Book B, p. 31; William Clayton Memorandum, 31 May 1845, p. 95; Temple Committee Ledger, Book C, p. 36; Temple Committee Place Book, p. 44; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Early Members of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, 8:209-11; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: CAHOON, Reynolds
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Cahoon Given name: Reynolds Birth date: 30 April 1790 Birth place: Cambridge, Washington, New York Father: Cahoon, William Jr. Mother: Hodges, Mehitable Spouse: Stiles, Thirza Marriage date: 11 December 1810 Marriage place: Newport, Herkimer, New York Spouse: Roberts, Lucina Marriage date: about 1842 Marriage date: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Hilgrath, Mary Marriage date: 16 January 1846 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Death date: 29 April 1861 Death place: South Cottonwood, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: In 1841 Reynolds paid taxes in Nauvoo. He performed at least one marriage in that community. He resided in the Nauvoo 3rd Ward. By March 1841 he was a citizen/soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He also served on the Temple Committee. He was endowed on 11 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. Sources: United States Federal Census, 1840, p. 199; Temple Carpenter Shop Account Book, pp. 26, 31, 39, 42, 43, 45, 49, 51, 53, 54, 55, 56; Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, p.122, Temple Committee Ledger, Book B, pp.18, 203, 355; Temple committee Ledger, Book D, p. 17; Temple Committee Day, Book A, pp. 334, 337; Nauvoo LDS Census, 1842; Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 233; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Early Members of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, 8:215-21; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:629-30.

personk.NAME: CAHOON, William F.
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Cahoon Given name: William Middle name: Farrington Birth date: 7 November 1813 Birth place: Harpersfield, Ashtabula, Ohio Father: Reynolds Cahoon Mother: Stiles, Thirza (Thira) Spouse: Gibbs, Nancy Maranda Marriage date: 17 January 1836 Marriage place: Kirtland, Geauga, Ohio Spouse: Jones, Elvina M. Marriage date: about 1838 Marriage place: of Harpersfield, Ashtabula, Ohio Spouse: Olsen, Oleana Marriage date: about 1838 Marriage place: of Harpersfield, Ashtabula, Ohio Spouse: Dugdale, Mary Wilson Marriage date: 23 September 1845 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Death date: 4 April 1893 Death place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Burial place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: William was baptized in 1830 and marched with in Zion's Camp in 1834. In Nauvoo, he served as the temple foreman over the raisers and timekeepers in the carpenter's shop. He was also a carpenter on the Nauvoo Temple. He lived in Zarahemla, Iowa. He was a member of the 1st and 2nd Quorum of the Seventy. He was endowed on 17 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. Sources: William Clayton Memorandum, 31 May 1845; Temple Carpenter Shop Account Book, pp. 26, 28, 31, 35, 38, 39, 47; Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, pp. 34, 222; Temple Committee Ledger, Book B, pp. 49, 132, 215, 348, 350; Temple Committee Ledger, Book C, p. 464; Temple Committee Ledger, Book D, p. 91; Temple Committee Carpenter Time, Book C; Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 4:687; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 8:225-30; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: CAIN, Joseph
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Cain Given name: Joseph Birth date: 5 November 1822 (1824) Birth place: Douglas, Isle of Man, England Father: Cain, James Mother: Moore, Ann Spouse: Whittaker (Whitaker), Elizabeth Marriage date: 1 February 1847 Marriage place: England Death date: 20 April 1857 Death place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: In 1844 Joseph migrated to the United States with his brother-in-law, John Taylor. He was employed in a printing shop in Nauvoo along with George Q. Cannon. He resided for a time with John Taylor. He was endowed on 24 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. By spring of 1846 he served a mission to England. In 1850 he was a deputy postmaster in Salt Lake City. He was a member of the 2nd Quorum of the Seventies. Sources: United States Federal Census, 1850; FamilySearch; International Genealogical Index; Esshom, Pioneers and Prominent Men of Utah, pp.106, 788; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 8:237-40; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: CAIRNS, John
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Cairns Given name: John Birth date: about 1821 Birth place: Scotland Spouse: (Cairns), Almira J. Comments: John was endowed on 5 February 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He moved from Nauvoo to St. Louis in 1846, where he became a prominent businessman. In 1870 John and his wife were residing in St. Louis, Missouri. At the time, John was referred to as a "market master" and had a real wealth of $50,000.00. He later affiliated with the RLDS Church. Sources: United States Federal Census, 1870; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 8:250; Black, Early Members of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, 2:15-16.

He moved to Nauvoo where he served as bishop of a ward east of the city and south of Knight Street. He was endowed on 25 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. By 1852 he was living in Kanesville, Iowa. personk.NAME: CALL, Anson
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Call Given name: Anson Birth date: 13 May 1810 Birth place: Fletcher, Franklin, Vermont Father: Call, Cyril Mother: Fiffany, Sally (Tiffany) Spouse: Flint, Mary Marriage date: 3 October 1833 Marriage place: Madison County, Ohio Spouse: Bowen, Anna Maria Marriage date: 16 April 1851 Spouse: Clark, Margaretta Marriage date: 7 February 1857 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Summers, Emma Marriage date: 24 February 1857 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: William, Henrietta Carolina Marriage date: 9 March 1861 Spouse: Clark, Ann Death date: 5 June 1890 Death place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: Anson performed several marriages in Nauvoo. He served as an officer in the Ramus Horse Lancers of the Nauvoo Legion. He was also a school trustee and a merchant. He eventually resided in the Nauvoo 5th Ward. He was endowed on 22 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. In 1850, 1870, and 1880 he was a resident of Davis County, Utah. Sources: Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, p.130; Diary of Anson call (BYU Library, M270.1 C13); United States Federal Census, 1840, p. 178a; United States Federal Census, 1850, 1870, 1880; Temple Committee Ledger, Book B, p. 288; Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 4:122, 621; Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 174; Trustees Deed Book; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 8:348-54; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:646-48.

During the burning of the Morley Settlement in 1845 he had "2 hewed log houses burned, worth a total of $500.00." He was endowed on 22 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. personk.NAME: CAMBRE, Eugene
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Cambre Given name: Eugene Birth date: 1823 Birth place: France Spouse: Harriet (Irma) Death date: about 1902 Death place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois
Comments: Eugene was a resident of Nauvoo from 1860-1870. In 1860 he was a cabinet maker with $1,000.00 in real wealth and $200.00 in personal wealth. In 1870 he was a "wine dresser" with a real wealth of $2,000.00 and a personal wealth of $500.00. He owned an old cello that was bought in 1900 for $1,800.00. He died in his home.
Sources: Nauvoo Independent, 6 April 1900; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; United States Federal Census, 1860, 1870, 1900.

personk.NAME: CARMICHAEL, William
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Carmichael Given name: William Birth date: 15 August 1804 Birth place: New York, New York Father: Carmichael, William Mother: Agnes Spouse: Wilson, Mary Ann (Mary Clark) Spouse: Wright, Emma Death date: 21 April 1868 Death place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: William was a joiner by trade. He was ordained a priest on 6 January 1844. He was a carver on the Nauvoo Temple. He was a member of the 25th Quorum of the Seventy. He was endowed on 19 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He resided in the Nauvoo 3rd Ward. He was very sick during the September 1846 Battle of Nauvoo. Sources: Temple Committee Ledger, Book B, pp. 278, 292; Temple Committee Ledger, Book D, p.180; Temple Committee Place Book, p.155; Temple Committee Carpenter Time, Book C; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 304; Salt Lake City Cemetery Records; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 8:669-70; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: CARNES, Daniel
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Carnes (Garn, Carn) Given name: Daniel Birth date: 13 December 1802 Birth place: St. Clair, Schuylkill, Pennsylvania Father: Carn (Garn) John (Johannes) Mother: Pringle, Susannah Spouse: Moses, Margaret Marriage date: 2 December 1824 Marriage place: St. Clair, Bedford, Pennsylvania Spouse: Marsteller, Priscilla Marriage date: 13 March 1847 Marriage place: Winter Quarters, Douglas, Nebraska Spouse: Charnes (Eharnes), Eliza Marriage date: 11 January 1855 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Wagner, Wilhelmina Marriage date: 31 January 1856 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Garn, Mahala Marriage date: 12 January 1858 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Death date: 22 April 1872 Death place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: On 16 July 1845 in the Nauvoo Neighbor appeared, "Daniel Carne will apply to County Commissioners ... for license to keep a ferry between Nauvoo and Montrose." He asked for volunteers from the Nauvoo 6th Ward to go to the Upper Steam Mill on the Big Island for wood for the poor. He served as bishop of the Nauvoo 6th Ward. He was endowed on 15 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. Sources: United States Federal Census, 1840, p. 181; William Clayton Memorandum, 31 May 1845; Temple Committee Ledger, Book D, p. 303; Temple committee Place Book, p. 62; Temple Carpenter Shop Account Book, pp. 42, 54, 55; Nauvoo City Treasury, pp. 111, 133; Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 113 (February 1842-July 1842); Nauvoo Neighbor, 31 January 1844; Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 228; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 8:671-73; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:665-69.

personk.NAME: CARTER, William
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Carter Given name: William Middle name: Furlsbury Birth date: 1 May 1811 Birth place: Newry, Oxford, Maine Father: Carter, John C. Mother: Libby, Hannah Knight Spouse: York, Sarah Marriage date: 1 March 1832 Marriage place: Bethel, Oxford, Maine Death date: 11 October 1888 Death place: Santaquin, Utah, Utah Comments: On 9 September 1845, William's shop burned, including tools, stoves, and barrels. He resided in the Nauvoo 2nd Ward on Block 7 with the Charles Thomas household. He was endowed on 20 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a member of the 20th Quorum of the Seventy. He was a pioneer in 1847. He is credited with performing the first "plowing" in the Salt Lake Valley. Sources: United States Federal Census, 1840, pp. 206, 215;United States Federal Census, 1880; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book A, p. 243; Nauvoo House Workmen's Book, p.10; Nauvoo Provision Store, pp. 29, 32, 35, 36, 40, 42, 45, 47, 50, 52; Ancestry.com (Mob Affadavit #40); Hancock County Taxes, 1842, pp. 164, 189; Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 4:695; Nauvoo LDS Census, 1842; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 9:81-83; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Clark Given name: Raymond Birth date: 14 February 1798 Birth place: Wells, Rutland, Vermont Father: Milton Mother: Parmelia Spouse: Gill, Louisa Comments: Raymond owned a store in Nauvoo that was frequented by many important members of the Nauvoo community, such as Heber C. He was endowed on 23 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. personk.NAME: CLAYTON, Thomas
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Clayton Given name: Thomas Birth date: 1794 Birth place: Penwortham, Lancashire, England Father: Clayton, Thomas Mother: Mayor, Ellen Spouse: Critchlow, Ann Marriage date: 1813 Death date: 16 June 1849 Death place: St. Louis, St. Louis, Missouri
Comments: Thomas was a half-brother to William Clayton. He arrived in Nauvoo in the early 1840s. His mother died in Nauvoo in 1848, and his father died in St. Louis in 1849. He had 21 children, 14 of whom came to Nauvoo.
Sources: Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 2:757; Temple Committee Place Book, p.201; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; International Genealogical Index.

personk.NAME: CLAYTON, William
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Clayton Given name: William Birth date: 17 July 1814 Birth place: Charnock Moss, Penwortham, Lancashire, England Father: Clayton, Thomas Mother: Critchlow, Ann Spouse: Moon, Ruth Marriage date: 9 October 1836 Marriage place: Penwortham, Lancashire, England Spouse name: Moon, Margaret Marriage date: 27 April 1843 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Hardman, Alice Marriage date: 13 September 1844 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Hardman, Jane Marriage date: 20 November 1844 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Farr, Diantha Marriage date: 9 July 1845 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Braddock, Augusta Marriage date: 5 October 1850 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Walters, Sarah Marriage date: 30 October 1850 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Lyman, Mary Louisa Marriage date: 3 October 1866 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Ainsworth, Elizabeth Marriage date: 19 December 1868 Spouse: Higgs, Anna Elizabeth Marriage date: 30 December 1870 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Death date: 4 (7) December 1879 Death place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: William arrived in Commerce on 23 October 1840, and lived together with William Poole's family for a time in a very small house on the banks of the Mississippi River. He was endowed on 11 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He wrote "Come, Come Ye Saints." He was a clerk for Joseph Smith and a recorder for the city of Nauvoo. He was also the secretary for the Masonic Lodge. On 8 June 1844 William buried the public records of Nauvoo. He was also a recorder for the Nauvoo Temple. He was an original pioneer in 1847 to Utah. He wrote a book, published in St. Louis, Missouri, called The Latter-day Saints' Emigrants' Guide. Sources: Masonic Proceedings; Smith, History of the Church, 7:129; William Clayton Memorandum, 31 May 1845, p. 91; Nauvoo City Treasury, p. 74; Trustees Deed, Book B; Temple Carpenter Shop Account Book, pp. 29, 30, 32, 33, 45, 46, 47; Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, pp. 238, 12a, 18; Temple Committee Ledger, Book B, pp. 57, 241, 282; Temple Committee Ledger, Book D, p. 109; Nauvoo Place Book, p.18; Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 217 (October 1842-June 1844); Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 228; David D. Yearsley Ledger, p. 28; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:805-06; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 10:300-09.

personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Code (Codde) Given name: Joseph Birth date: about 1818 Father: Code, Joseph Spouse: Dodge, Melissa Marriage date: 3 April 1845 Marriage place: Hancock County, Illinois Comments: Joseph received his patriarchal blessing in 1843. He was endowed on 28 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He and Melissa were married by George C. Wilson. On 26 December 1844, Joseph was listed as a priest. A possibly different Joseph Code reported in the Nauvoo Neighbor of 23 December 1844 that "my wife, Lydia Code, has left my bed and board, etc." Sources: Hancock County Marriages, p. 85; Lesser Priesthood Census, 1841-1844; Nauvoo Neighbor, 23 December 1844; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:839-49; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 10:650; International Genealogical Index.

personk.NAME: COLE, Joseph H.
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Cole Given name: Joseph Middle name: H. Birth date: about 1806 Birth place: of Steuben County, New York Father: Cole, Joseph Mother: Gordon, Ruth Spouse: James, Eliza Comments: In 1850 Joseph was residing in Hancock County, Illinois. He was a school inspector. He had what was described as a select school, which apparently disturbed the peace and quiet that Willard Richards and W. W. Phelps needed to write the History of the Church on the floor below, in the first floor of the Red Brick store. Thus, he was asked to remove his school from that building into another, and he did so. Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Ancestral File; United States Federal Census, 1850; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:853-56.

personk.NAME: COLTON, Philander
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Colton Given name: Philander Birth date: 11 January 1811 (19 October 1811) Birth place: Clarence, Niagra, New York (Clarence Hollow, Erie, New York) Father: Colton, Charles Mother: Jones, Polly (Mary) Spouse: Merrill, Polly Matilda Marriage date: 3 July 1833 Marriage place: Near Utica, Macomb, Michigan Death date: 15 August 1891 Death place: Vernal, Uintah, Utah Burial place: Maeser, Uintah, Utah Comments: Philander was a mason, plasterer and brick maker by trade. He was a member of the 12th Quorum of the Seventy. He was endowed on 31 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. Occasionally, he also worked in a leather manufactory. He was a member of the Mormon Battalion. Sources: Esshom, Pioneers and Prominent Men of Utah; Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 210; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book A, pp. 361, 428; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book B, p. 64; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 215; United States Federal Census, 1840, p. 160a; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 11:173-77; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: COLTRIN, Graham

He was ordained a high priest. He was a frequent shopper at Joseph Smith's Red Brick Store. He and his wife, Harriet, were married by Isaac Higbee. He resided in the Nauvoo 1st Ward. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was endowed on 22 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. Sources: United States Federal Census, 1840, p. 167; Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 216; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 254; Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, p. 51, Nauvoo House Ledger, Book B, p. 167; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book D, p. 125; Temple Committee Carpenter Time, Book C; Temple Committee Place Book, p. 24; Hancock Marriages, p. 41; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 11:185-88.

Gender: Male Surname: Compton Given name: Griffith Middle name: Dickinson Birth date: 22 August 1820 Birth place: Virginia Spouse: Lucy Jane Marriage date: 25 November 1840 Marriage place: Hamilton, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Flood, Emily Marriage date: 4 July 1853 Marriage place: California Death date: about 1904

personk.NAME: COMSTOCK, George F.
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Comstock Given name: George Middle name: Franklin Birth date: 24 August 1811 Birth place: Williamstown, Oswego, New York Father: Comstock, Serajah Mother: Austin, Climena Spouse: Noxon, Cornelia Marriage date: 15 October 1839 Marriage place: Syracuse, Onondaga, New York Death date: 27 September 1892 Death place: Syracuse, Onondaga, New York
Comments: George was a lawyer in the law firm of Noxon and Leavenworth in Syracuse in 1835. He was admitted to the bar in 1837. By 1847 he was a reporter for the New York Court of Appeals. In 1849 he helped organize the Syracuse Savings Bank. In 1852 he was appointed by President Fillmore to be solicitor of the United States Treasurey. He was also appointed to be a judge of the Court of Appeals.
Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Ancestry.com; International Genealogical Index.

He was the lookout on the tower of the Nauvoo Temple during the Battle of Nauvoo in September 1846. personk.NAME: COOLIDGE, Joseph Wellington
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Coolidge (Cooledge) Given name: Joseph Middle name: Wellington Birth date: 31 May 1814 Birth place: Bangor, Penobscot, Maine Father: Coolidge, John Kittridge Mother: Wellington, Rebecca Stone Spouse: Buchanan (Buchanon), Elizabeth Marriage date: 17 December 1834 Marriage place: Taswell (Tazewell), Illinois Spouse: Tuttle, Elizabeth (Eliza Jane) Marriage date: 21 January 1846 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Atwood, Rebecca Marriage date: 26 January 1846 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Carter, Rosilla (Rozilla) Milla Death date: 15 (13) January 1871 Death place: Glenwood, Mills, Iowa Comments: Joseph was ordained a seventy and endowed on 16 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He served as an administrator for the Joseph Smith estate. He was a merchant, carpenter and joiner and was heavily involved in stocking the Latter-day Saints up with necessary supplies and wagon parts for their emigration to Utah. He resided in the Nauvoo 4th Ward. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He performed at least one marriage in Nauvoo. He was arrested for destroying the Nauvoo Expositor press in 1844. Sources: Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, p. 156; David D. Yearsley Ledger, p. 14; Nauvoo Neighbor, 20 September 1843, p. 3; Nauvoo Neighbor, 12 March 1845; Nauvoo Neighbor, 23 March 1845; Smith, History of the Church, 6:460, 488-91; Smith, History of the Church, 7:67; Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 229; Temple Committee Carpenter Time, Book C; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book A, p. 5; Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 205 (January 1842-June 1844); United States Federal Census, 1840, p. 182a; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:888-94; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 11:461-64; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: CORNISH, Denman
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Cornish Given name: Denman (Deman) Birth date: 7 July 1822 Birth place: Rutland, Rutland, Vermont Father: Cornish, Benjamin Mother: Lucy Spouse: Mary C. Comments: "On the 28th of August I left my home and started for Nauvoo. On the 10th of October, I arrived in the City. I made it my home to Mr. Harrison Burgess. At which place I remained most of the time during the fall and winter and upon enquiring into the principles of the Saints, I found they held to the principles of life and salvation, and I soon became obedient to the Gospel of Christ," wrote Denman. He was a member of the 2nd Quorum of the Seventy. He was excommunicated from the Church. Sources: Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: COULSON, George
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Coulson Given name: George Birth date: 22 September 1802 Birth place: Belfast, Down, Ireland Father: Coulson, Thomas Mother: Maxwell, Fanny Spouse: Cossitt, Nancy Ann Spouse: Ackman, Lydia Death date: 8 October 1851 Death place: Council Bluffs, Pottawattamie, Iowa Comments: George lived in the area of LaHarpe, Hancock County, before the Saints arrived in 1839. After they settled in Nauvoo, George converted to the Church. He performed marriages, and was a judge and doctor in Hancock County. He was endowed on 24 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He left with the Saints from Nauvoo and began to the trek to the Rockies.. He died en route in either Iowa or Nebraska. Sources: United States Federal Census, 1840; Hancock County Marriages; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Ancestry.com; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:903-05; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 11:783-84.

personk.NAME: COWLES, Austin
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Cowles Given name: Austin Middle name: A. Birth date: 3 May 1792 Birth place: Brookfield, Orange, Vermont Father: Cowles, Timothy Mother: Woodworth, Abigail Spouse: Wilbur, Phebe Marriage date: 14 January 1813 Marriage place: Unadilla, Otsego, New York Spouse: Elliot, Irena Hix Marriage date: 21 October 1827 Marriage place: Amity Harbor, Suffolk, New York Death date: 15 December 1872 Death place: Pleasanton, Decatur, Iowa Comments: Austin resided in the Nauvoo 4th Ward. He worked as a merchant. He was selected as the first city street supervisor of Nauvoo on 3 February 1841. He was closely associated with Joseph Smith, but left his fellowship over the teaching of plurality of wives. He attended an apostate meeting on 28 April 1844. He was a Mason. He performed at least one marriage in Hancock County. He became an ally of William Lawâ€“a dissenter. He later affiliated with the RLDS Church. Sources: Nauvoo Merchant License Register, p. 2; Hancock County Taxes, p. 230; Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 73 (February 1842-August 1842); Hancock County Marriages, p. 44; United States Federal Census, 1840, p. 181; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Early Members of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, 2:334; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:910-11; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 12:127-29.

personk.NAME: CUTLER, Alpheus
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Cutler Given name: (John) Alpheus Birth date: 29 February 1784 Birth place: Upper Lisle, Cheshire, New Hampshire Father: Cutler, Knight Mother: Boyd, Elizabeth Mother variant: Boyd, Betsey Spouse: Lathrop (Lethrop) , Lois Marriage date: 17 November 1808 Marriage place: Lebanon, Grafton, New Hampshire Spouse: Beebe, Luanna Marriage date: 14 January 1846 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Death date: 10 August 1864 Death place: Manti, Fremont, Iowa Comments: Alpheus was as member of the Nauvoo Agricultural and Manufacturing Association. He was also on the Temple Committee. He was in the Legion Guard on 4 February 1841 and on the High Council in October 1839. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was endowed on 11 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He went with Brigham Young to Kanesville, but apostatized in Iowa. He organized an apostate church called The Church of Latter-day Saints. He rejected polygamy and tithing. He supported Joseph Smith, not Brigham Young. Sources: Carter, Our Pioneer Heritage, 10; United States Federal Census, 1840; Amos Davis Account Book; Temple Carpenter Account Book, pp. 29, 31, 41, 42, 49, 53; Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, B pp.236, 351; Temple Committee Ledger, Book D, p. 16; Hancock County Taxes, p. 199; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 12: 808-13.

In Nauvoo, he was a teamster who drew stone to the cranes. He went to Utah in 1848. William was a manager of a co-op store in Parowan, Utah, in 1880. Comments: In 1850 Bailey was a farmer in Rock Island, Illinois. He had a real wealth of $20,000.00. In 1860 he was a farmer in Rock Island with a real wealth of $40,000.00 and a personal wealth of $3,500.00. By 1870 he was a capitalist with a real wealth of $200,000.00 and a personal wealth of $10,000.00. By 1880, he was a bank president.

personk.NAME: DAVENPORT, George
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Davenport Given name: George Birth date: about 1781 Birth place: Surrey, North Carolina (Lincolnshire, England) Father: Davenport, William Mother: Fisher, Comfort Spouse: (Indian woman) Spouse: Clifton, Nancy Winnie Marriage date: 9 December 1809 (5 September 1810) Spouse: Murray, Rhoda Death date: 14 February 1845 Death place: Rock Island County (Sangamon County), Illinois
Comments: George was an Indian agent for the American Fur Company in Rock Island, Illinois. He signed the treaty with Chief Keokuk in 1822. By 1840 he was residing in Rock Island County, Illinois. In 1845 he was robbed and murdered by "white desperados in Rock Island."
Sources: United States Federal Census, 1840; International Genealogical Index; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: DAVIS, Amos
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Davis Given name: Amos Birth date: 29 December 1814 Birth place: Hopkington, Rockingham, New Hampshire Spouse: Hibbard, Elvira Maria Marriage date: 1 January 1837 Spouse: Andrus, Harriet Louise Marriage date: 27 January 1850 Marriage place: Hancock County, Illinois Spouse: Isenberger, Mary Jane Marriage date: 12 April 1866 Marriage place: Hancock County, Illinois Death date: 22 March 1872 Death place: Appanoose, Hancock, Illinois
Comments: Amos was a graduate of the University of Vermont. He was apparently one of the first settlers of the Appanoose area in around 1836. There he built a house with an orchard, some shade trees, and a barn at the location called the "Big Mound." He was a postmaster in 1839. He was a storekeeper in Nauvoo and kept his own account book. He was a 1st Lieutenant in the Nauvoo Legion as of 4 February 1841. In January 1846, Elvira and Amos filed for a divorce, but it appears that it was never made final. He is connected with a mob lynching of some harvesters in the Nauvoo area on 4 July 1846. He was in Nauvoo during the Battle of Nauvoo and was friendly (he didn't fight against the Mormons), but he ran away from the fight. In 1850 Amos was residing in Hancock County, Illinois. By 1870 he was a farmer with $48,000.00 in real wealth and $6,000.00 in personal wealth.
Sources: Ancestral File; International Genealogical Index; Merchants and Grocers Licenses Fees, pp. 1, 3, 4; Hancock County Circuit Court File, p. 147; Hancock County Tax Register, 1850; Alexander Neibar Journal; Amos Davis Account Book, p. 3 (28 December 1838); Amos Davis Account Book, p. 32; Amos Davis Account Book, p. 29 (23 May 1838); Amos Davis Account Book, p. 92 (11 November 1839); Temple Committee Ledger, Book D, p. 375; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: DAVIS, Daniel
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Davis Given name: Daniel Middle name: Coon Birth date: 23 February 1804 Birth place: Petersburgh, Rensselaer, New York Father: Davis, William Mother: Coon, Miriam Spouse: Fuller, Sophronia Marriage date: about 1827 Marriage place: Jefferson, Schoharie, New York Spouse: Moses, Susan (Susanna) Marriage date: 4 March 1844 Marriage place: Montrose, Lee, Iowa Death date: 1 June 1850 Death place: Ft. Kearney, Otoe, Nebraska Comments: There is a question as to whether this is the right Daniel Davis. There is also a Daniel Davis who is the brother of Amos Davis. Daniel was a ferryman in October 1839. He earned $30.00 a month in this occupation. He served on the Nauvoo High Council in 1839. He was a Mason. He was endowed on 30 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was ordained a seventy. He served as a captain in Company E of the Mormon Battalion. Davis County, Utah, was named after Daniel Davis. Sources: Nauvoo House Ledger, Book A, p. 153; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 179; *Smith, History of the Church, 4:16 [Marci, please check for usâ€“thanks!]; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 13:364-66; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:982-83.

personk.NAME: ELLISON, Matthew
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Ellison Given name: Matthew Birth date: 15 (8) September 1793 Birth place: of Chipping, Lancashire, England Spouse: Wilson, Jane Marriage date: 11 March 1817 Marriage place: England Death date: 11 March 1865 Death place: Rock Creek, Hancock, Illinois
Comments: Matthew worked in a factory before emigrating to America. He attended the coronation of Queen Victoria in 1837. He was one of the first to accept the gospel in England in 1837. When he arrived in Nauvoo, he became a farmer. In 1850 he was residing in Hancock County, Illinois. By 1860 he was a farmer in Rock Creek, Hancock, Illinois. He had a real wealth of $900.00 and a personal wealth of $1,300.00.
Sources: Ancestry.com; International Genealogical Index; United States Federal Census, 1850, 1860; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: ELLS, Josiah
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Ells Given name: Josiah Birth date: 4 March 1806 Birth place: Lewis, Essex, England Father: Ells, Thomas Spouse: Anne Spouse: Campion, Eliza L. Death date: 15 October 1885 Death place: Wheeling, Ohio, West Virginia Comments: Josiah was baptized into the LDS Church on 1 October 1838 in New Jersey. He came to Nauvoo in 1840. He leased property from Charles Ivins. He accompanied the Prophet Joseph Smith on his way to Carthage. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. After the death of Joseph Smith, Josiah was chosen as a counselor in Sidney Rigdon's church, but was never active in that position. However, by 1860 he was residing in near Rigdon in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He joined the RLDS movement and became an apostle in that church. Sources: Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 181; United States Federal Census, 1850, 1860; Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Early Members of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, 2:659-60; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 15:407-08.

personk.NAME: FIDOE, John
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Fido(Fidoe) Given name: John Birth date: 16 September (May) 1796 Birth place: Whitbourne, Herefordshire, England Father: Fido, John Mother : Taylor, Ann (Nancy) Spouse: Pulling, Lydia Marriage date: 3 December 1839 Marriage place: Bishop's Frome, Herefordshire, England Death date: 23 July 1881 Death place: Columbus, Franklin, Ohio Burial Date: 24 July 1881 Burial place: Green Lawn Cemetery, Columbus, Franklin, Ohio Comments: At an early age, John joined the British Naval Service. Later he enlisted in the British Army, serving his country about seventeen years. In 1844 he settled in Columbus, Ohio. He did not remain there long. He settled in Nauvoo. He was endowed on 17 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was ordained a high priest. He served in the 20th Quorum of the Seventies in Nauvoo. On 18 October 1841 he received his patriarchal blessing from Hyrum Smith in Nauvoo. Sources: Nauvoo LDS Census 1842; Patriarchal Blessing Book Index, 4:94; Nauvoo 2nd Ward Records; Temple Committee Carpenter Shop Account Book, p. 35; Temple Committee Place Book, p. 40; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book A, pp. 75, 252, 358, 423; Hancock County Taxes, 1842; Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 16:202; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 2:1248-50.

personk.NAME: GODDARD, Stephen H.
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Goddard (Godard) Given name: Stephen Middle name: Hezekiah Birth date: 23 August 1810 Birth place: Champlain, Clinton, New York Father: Goddard, Stephen G. Mother: Smith, Sylvia Spouse: Bisbee, Isabella Marriage date: 14 November 1833 Marriage place: McDonough, Chautauqua, New York Spouse: Rhody, Larena Marriage date: 11 September 1839 Marriage place: Adams County, Illinois Spouse: Alamantha Marriage date: by 1846 Spouse: Roby, Zeruah Norwood Marriage date: by 1846 Spouse: Vaugn, Lucinda Marriage date: 1847 Spouse: Lewis, Mary Ann Sears Marriage date: 27 November 1871 Death date: 10 September 1898 Death place: San Bernardino County, California Comments: Stephen was endowed on 20 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was ordained a seventy in 1847 and was a member of the 27th Quorum of the Seventy. He resided in the Nauvoo 3rd Ward. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was a pioneer in 1847. It was said of him that he was the finest looking man in the pioneer company. He was the director of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir. It is reported that he led the first choir in Salt Lake City. Sources: International Genealogical Index; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 3:1424-25; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 18:566-69; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: GRAY, James
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Gray Given name: James Birth date: about 1805 Birth place: Scotland Spouse: Carr, Mary Ann Marriage date: about 1832 Death date: 3 October 1868 Death place: Sutter, Sutter, California
Comment: In 1829 James came with his brother to the United States. He was a millwright in the East for several years. He was a farmer 40 miles north of Keokuk, Lee County, Iowa before moving to Hancock County, Illinois. He was active in driving the Mormons out of Hancock County. In 1850 he was a carpenter in Hancock County. He had a real wealth of $1,600.00. In 1852 he moved his family to San Francisco. He settled in Yuba City, where he acquired 160 acres at first and later 800 acres.
Sources: Hancock County Taxes, 1842; United States Federal Census, 1850; Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.
