personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Hale Given name: Jonathan Middle name: Harrison Birth date: 1 February 1800 Birth place: Groveland, Essex, Massachusetts Father: Hale, Solomon Mother: Harrison, Martha Spouse: Boynton, Olive Marriage date: 1 September 1825 Marriage place: Groveland, Essex, Massachusetts Death date: 4 September 1846 Death place: Council Bluffs, Pottawattamie, Iowa Comments: In 1842 Jonathon was bishop of the Nauvoo 9th Ward. He was a member of the 3rd Quorum of the Seventy. The 10th Quorum of the Seventy met in his home on 18 December 1844. In 1844 he was the assessor and collector of the Nauvoo 3rd Ward. He was endowed on 22 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He and his wife died in Winter Quarters in 1846-1847. personk.NAME: HUNTINGTON, Dimick
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Huntington Given name: Dimick Middle name: Baker Birth date: 26 May 1808 Birth place: Watertown, Jefferson, New York Father: Huntington, William Mother: Baker, Zina Spouse: Allen, Fannie Marie Marriage date: 28 April 1830 Spouse: Jacobson, Ellen Sophia Death date: 1 February 1879 Death place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: Dimick was the high constable and collector for the Nauvoo Legion and was commissioned in March 1841. He was elected coroner of Nauvoo on 23 May 1842. He resided in the Nauvoo 4th Ward and participated in the burial of Joseph Smith in the cellar of the unfinished Nauvoo House on 29 June, 1844. He was endowed on 20 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was a private in Company D of the Mormon Battalion. Sources: David D. Yearsley Ledger, p. 28; Smith, History of the Church, 5:18; "Law of the Lord" and Consecration Accounts, p. 60; Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 118 (March 1842-September 1842); Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 231; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book A, p. 37; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book B, p. 73; Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, p. 28; Temple Committee Place Book, p. 9; Nauvoo LDS Census, 1842, p. 47; Nauvoo City Treasury, p. 53; Ancestral File; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 24:752-57; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 3:1852-53.

personk.NAME: HUNTINGTON, William D.
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Huntington Given name: William Middle name: Dresser Birth date: 18 February 1818 Birth place: Watertown, Jefferson, New York Father: Huntington, William Mother: Baker, Zina Spouse: Clark, Caroline Marriage date: 24 September 1839 Marriage place: Hancock County, Illinois Death date: 20 March 1881 Death place: Springville, Utah, Utah Comments: William left Missouri in February 1839 and arrived in Nauvoo on 3 April 1839. He lived with Joseph Smith until 1 September 1839. William and Caroline were married by Don Carlos Smith. William resided in the Nauvoo 4th Ward. He participated in the burial of Joseph Smith in the cellar of the unfinished Nauvoo House on 29 June 1844. He was a member of the 2nd and 3rd Quorums of the Seventy. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was endowed on 20 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. personk.NAME: IVIE, Thomas Celton
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Ivie Given name: Thomas Middle name: Celton Birth date: 25 August 1820 Birth place: on Duck River, Bedford, Tennessee Father: Ivie, John Anderson Mother: Allred, Sarah (Sally) Spouse: Moore, Amanda Jane Marriage date: 24 August 1844 (21 February 1852) Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Death date: 1864 Death place: Missouri Comments: Thomas was a member of the 4th Quorum of the Seventy. He was endowed on 24 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a private in Company C of the Mormon Battalion. He was tried for murder. Apparently a conflict arose over a payment of sheep. He was found guilty and condemned to death. He escaped to Missouri. The man killed was Isaac Allred of Mt. Pleasant, Sanpete, Utah. Sources: Ancestry.com; Jenson, Church Chronology, 11 May 1859; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 25:53-54; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: IVINS, Charles H.
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Ivins Given name: Charles Middle name: H. Birth date: 16 April 1799 Birth place: Upper, Freehold, Monmouth, New Jersey Father: Ivins, Israel Mother: Woodward, Margaret Spouse: Elizabeth S. Marriage date: May 1823 Marriage place: of New Jersey Spouse: Cole Marriage date: 17 October 1850 Marriage place: Keokuk, Lee, Iowa Spouse: Annie Death date: 29 January 1875 Death place: Burlington, Lee, Iowa
Comments: Charles arrived in Nauvoo in 1841 with a company of Latter-day Saints from New Jersey. He became a hotel keeper. He ran the Ivins House or what was referred to as the Nauvoo Ferry Hotel. He was also a co-publisher of the Nauvoo Expositor. He became an apostate. In 1850 Charles was a hotel keeper in Keokuk, Lee, Iowa. In 1870 he was a farmer in the same community with a real wealth of $5,000.00 and a personal wealth of $1,000.00.
Sources: United States Federal Census 1850, 1870; Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Times and Seasons, 1 May 1841; Roberts, Comprehensive History of the Church, 2:227; Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 767; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book A, p. 184; Hancock County Taxes, 1842.

He was baptized on 20 July 1843 by Eli Maguin He received his patriarchal blessing on 25 December 1844 in Nauvoo from Uncle John Smith. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was endowed on 17 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. In 1850 he was a farmer in Nauvoo with a real wealth of $6,000.00. He died in a ship explosion en route to the mission field . personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Kimball Given name: Oliver Birth date: January 1817 Birth place: Grafton, Worchester, Massachusetts Spouse: Heywood, Sara Merriam Marriage date: 14 April 1841 Marriage place: Grafton, Worchester, Massachusetts Death date: 3 May 1886
Comments: Oliver was a partner of Joseph L. Heywood. They were merchants in the Knowlton Settlement and Nauvoo. He was the brother-in-law of Joseph Heywood.
Sources Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Ancestral File; Ancestry.com; International Genealogical Index.

personk.NAME: KIMBALL, Phineas
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Kimball Given name: Phineas Birth date: 1 May 1822 Birth place: West Fairlee, Orange County, Vermont Father: Kimball, Phineas Mother: Colton, Abigail Spouse: Bartholomew, Louisa L. Marriage date: 1857 Spouse: Icking, Dina Marriage date: 25 July 1866 Death date: 7 October 1900
Comments: At age 19, Phineas was a clerk in the mercantile business of his brother Hiram Kimball. He carried the ammunition in the September 1846 Battle of Nauvoo. He was not a Mormon, but a man of honor and strict veracity. He came to Kanesville from Nauvoo to bring goods to his Mormon friends. He went on to California in 1849 during the gold rush. In 1852 he returned to Nauvoo and operated a foundry. By 1870 he was a farmer in Nauvoo with a real wealth of $40,000.00 and a personal wealth of $5,250.00.
Sources: Frontier Guardian, 4 April 1849; United States Federal Census, 1850, 1860, 1870, 1880, 1900; International Genealogical Index; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: MAUGHAN, Peter
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Maughan Given name: Peter Birth date: 7 May 1811 Birth place: Alston (Milton, Farlam, Breckenridge), Cumberland, England Father: Maughan, William Mother: Walton (Wilson), Martha Spouse: Harrison, Ruth Marriage date: 1828 (1830, 1829) Marriage place: Alston, Cumberland, England Spouse: Weston, Mary Ann Marriage date: 2 November 1841 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Hobson, Sarah Marriage date: 1 November 1861 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Preator, Elizabeth Francis Marriage date: 8 December 1866 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Death date: 24 April 1871 Death place: Logan, Cache, Utah Burial date: 26 April 1871 Burial place: Logan, Cache, Utah Comments: Peter was a well digger and a miner. During the winter of 1841-1842 he lived in the Orson Hyde home in Nauvoo while Orson was on a mission. At this time he exchanged goods from England for food and clothing. He paid for his lot by laboring on the Nauvoo Temple as a stone mason in spring 1844. He was later sent to locate a coal mine on the Mississippi River. He was endowed on 2 February 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. Sources: Nauvoo 3rd Ward Records; Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 3; Hancock County Taxes, 1842; Ancestral File; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 29: 721-27; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 4:2342-44.

personk.NAME: MCAULEY, John
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: McAuley (McCauley) Given name: John Birth date: 9 September 1800 Birth place: Cambridge, Washington, New York Father: McAuley, Peter Mother: Dawson, Janet Spouse: Van Tassel, Mary (Polly) Marriage date: 24 April 1823 Death date: 17 January 1884 Death place: Carthage, Hancock, Illinois Comments: John came to Nauvoo between 1841-1843. He was endowed on 7 February 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He served as a Justice of the Peace in Pontoosuc, Hancock, Illinois. It was reported that he was a "notorious mobocrat." After the death of Joseph Smith, he told Mr. L. Morrill that he would die a happy man if he could blot out five years of his life. In 1860 and 1870 he was a farmer in Appanoose, Hancock County. He had a real wealth of $4,000.00 and a personal wealth of $700.00. Sources: United States Federal Census, 1860, 1870; Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 29:881.

personk.NAME: MENDENHALL, Jacob
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Mendenhall Given name: Jacob Birth date: 7 October 1784 Birth place: Guilford County, North Carolina Father: Mendenhall, Isaac M. Mother: Hoggatt, Rachel Spouse: Lamb, Rachel Marriage date: 11 January 1810 Marriage place: Clark County, Indiana Spouse: Hoggart, Nancy Marriage date: 20 May 1819 Marriage place: Salem, Washington, Indiana Death date: 21 January (31 January) 1857 Death place: Durham, Hancock, Illinois
Comments: In 1844 Jacob resided in Wilmington, Iowa. In 1850 he resided in Hancock County, Illinois. It was reported that he employed Mormons that had been driven from Missouri until he claimed that Mormons stole his horse, saddle and bridle. This so angered him that he ultimately drove them from Hancock County.
Sources: United States Census, 1840, 1850; Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: MENDENHALL, James

He was also a merchant and a brick mason. He was endowed in the Nauvoo Temple on 24 January 1846. Sources: Nauvoo Neighbor, 25 December 1844; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 192; Ancestral File; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 30:660-61.

He was a member of the 11th Quorum of the Seventy. He was endowed on 6 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. personk.NAME: MERRYWEATHER, Frederick
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Merryweather Given name: Frederick Birth date: 23 March 1805 Birth place: London, Middlesex, England Father: Merryweather, William Mother: Sumner, Isabella (Mary) Spouse: Arnold, Sarah Marriage date: 20 June 1837 Marriage place: Hamilton County, Ohio Comments: Frederick opened a new store filled with dry goods and groceries on 13 March 1844 on Main Streeet in Nauvoo. He got a one year business license for $7.00. He received his patriarchal blessing in 1843. He was a member of the 8th Quorum of the Seventy. In 1850 he was a patent medicine agent in Cincinnati, Ohio. By 1860 he was a doctor in the same community with $3,000.00 of real wealth. In 1870 he was a physician in Sacto, California. W. Miller. He was endowed on 17 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. personk.NAME: MILLER, George
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Miller Given name: George Birth date: 25 November 1794 Birth place: Standardsville, Orange, Virginia Father: Miller, John Mother: Pfeiffer, Margaret Spouse: Fry, Mary Catherine Marriage date: 25 June 1822 Marriage place: Madison County, Virginia Death date: 1855 Death place: McHenry, Illinois (en route to California) Comments: George received a patriarchal blessing on 4 July 1840. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He served as bishop of the Nauvoo 1st Ward. He was president of the Nauvoo House Association and trustee of the Nauvoo Temple. He succeeded Bishop Edward Partridge as Bishop of the Upper Ward. He was endowed on 10 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple and ordained a high priest. He was with James Strang in 1850. He later joined with Lyman Wight. Sources: Hancock County Taxes, 1842; Temple Committee Ledger, Book B, pp. 318. 321; Temple Carpenter Account Book, pp. 27, 32, 40, 46; Listing of Nauvoo Agricultural and Manufacturing Association; Nauvoo House Stock Record Book, 1841; United States Federal Census, 1840; Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 30:991-94; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 4:2486-88.

personk.NAME: MILLER, Henry William
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Miller Given name: Henry Middle name: William Birth date: 1 May 1807 Birth place: Lexington, Greene, New York Father: Miller, James Gardner Mother: Arnold, Ruth Spouse: Pond, Elmira (Almira) Marriage date: 19 June 1831 Marriage place: Quincy, Adams, Illinois Spouse: Gunn, Fannie Marriage date: 25 October 1862 Marriage place: Endowment House, Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Death date: 9 October 1885 Death place: Farmington, Davis, Utah Burial place: Farmington, Davis, Utah Comments: Henry resided in the Nauvoo 4th Ward. At the dedication of the Masonic Hall in Nauvoo, the processional formed at his house. He was endowed on 23 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was a carpenter and builder and was appointed as a sheriff in Hancock County on 14 March 1846. In 1850 he was a merchant in Pottawattamie, Iowa. By 1860 he was a farmer in Farmington, Davis, Utah. He had a real wealth of $1,500.00. In 1870 and 1880 he was a farmer in St. George, Washington, Utah. Sources: Nauvoo Municipal Court Docket, p. 1; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book A, pp. 134, 146; United States Federal Census, 1850, 1860, 1870, 1880; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 31:1-7.

Comments: Milton was an attorney. It is reported that he assisted in defending Nauvoo in September 1846. He was mayor of Nauvoo for ten years and served several times in the legislature. In 1860 he was a lawyer and a general assembly man in Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois. In 1880 he was still residing in Nauvoo.

Comments: Isaac was a member of the Illinois State Legislature. He was appointed Secretary of State in 1840 by Governor Carlin but declined to serve. In 1850 he was residing in Ellington, Adams, Illinois. He represented Illinois in the 35th and 36th congresses from 1857-1861. In 1870 he was a lawyer in Quincy, Adams County, Illinois. He had a real wealth of $200,000.00 and a personal wealth of $20,000.00.

personk.NAME: MULLINER, Samuel
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Mulliner (Mullinreet) Given name: Samuel Birth date: 15 (13) January 1809 (25 January 1808, 15 January 1807) Birth place: Haddington, East Lothian, Scotland Father: Mulliner (Mullinger), Samuel Mother: Sutherland, Janet Spouse: Nesbit (Hisbit), Catherine Marriage date: 4 December 1830 Marriage place: Scotland Spouse: Berry, Harriet Amelia Marriage date: 15 April 1847 Spouse: Richardson, Mary Ann Marriage date: 4 December 1850 Spouse: Royal, Ann Death date: 25 (23, 24) February 1891 (1894) Death place: Lehi, Utah, Utah Burial date: 27 February 1891 Burial place: Lehi, Utah, Utah Comments: Samuel was the first missionary to Scotland in 1839. He later resided in the Nauvoo 5th Ward. He was president of the Nauvoo Leather, Harness, Boot and Shoe Manufactory just below Young Street. He was one of the presidents of the 12th Quorum of the Seventy. He was ordained a seventy and endowed on 24 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. In 1850 he was a shoemaker and by 1870 a miller. Sources: United States Federal Census, 1850, 1870; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 31:966-67; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

personk.NAME: NOBLE, Abner
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Noble Given name: Abner Middle name: Legrand Birth date: 12 June 1822 Birth place: Madison County, Kentucky Father: Noble, William Mother: Ransom, Eleanor Spouse: Serrot, Catherine Marriage date: 28 October 1845 Death date: 31 January 1899 Death place: Rushville, Schuyler, Illinois
Comments: At age 12 Abner came with his parents to Illinois. He received a limited education and assisted his father on the farm. He learned the cooper's trade and opened a shop in Rushville. Due to ill health, he closed his business. In 1847 he was elected constable of the community. He served in this capacity for 35 years. He and his wife were members of the Methodist Episcopal Church. In 1860 he was a constable in Rushville with a real wealth fo $2,100.00 and a personal wealth of $300.00. In 1870 he was a speculator in the same community with a real wealth of $10,000.00 and a personal wealth of $500.00.
Sources: Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; United States Federal Census, 1860, 1870.

Comments: In 1850 Rufus was a blacksmith in Hancock County, Illinois. He had a real wealth of $250.00. By 1870 he was a blacksmith in La Harpe, Hancock County, Illinois. He accumulated $400.00 in real wealth and $100.00 in personal wealth. He petitioned in December 1843 to the United States Congress for a mail route from McComb, McDonough County, via small towns in Hancock County, to Nauvoo. He was married to Mary Cogswell by James Reynolds, Justice of the Peace.

Comments: In 1846 Joseph was residing in Durham, Hancock, Illinois. He lived in a large stone house on rolling prairie ground. On this land he raised horses which were sold in New York. In 1850 he had a real wealth of $1,200.00. By 1860 he had a real wealth of $4,800.00 and a personal wealth of $1,000.00. He became a recruiting officer for the Union Army. He and his wife moved to Kansas in 1880, where he became a farmer, grocer, and stock dealer.

personk.NAME: OWEN, Thomas Harvey
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Owen Given name: Thomas Middle name: Harvey Birth date: 25 June 1797 Birth place: Buncombe County, North Carolina Spouse: Wrem, Mary Ann Marriage date: April 1818 Death date: 22 February 1880 Death place: Santa Rosa, Sonoma, California Burial date: 27 February 1880 Burial place: Fairfield Cemetery, Suisun, Solano, California
Comments: In 1820 Thomas was living in Franklin County, Illinois. He became a Baptist minister. He fought in the War of 1812. He left Illinois for California and was reported as being in Tuolumne by 1850. In 1870 he was a farmer in Lake County, California with $1,500.00 in personal wealth. In 1831 he was the first settler in Carthage, Hancock, Illinois. He was a Justice of the Peace. He was also associated with a ferry franchise. At one point, he was an assistant marshal. By 1860 he had removed to California.
Sources: United States Federal Census, 1820, 1840, 1850, 1860, 1870; Ancestry.com; Ancestry World Tree Project (North and South, Union Regular Baptist Church); Hancock County Taxes, 1842; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: OWEN, William Pinckney
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Owen Given name: William Middle name: Pinckney Birth date: 6 March 1813 Birth place: Bedford County, Tennessee Spouse: Bruce, Eliza Jane Marriage date: 7 September 1843 Death date: 1 January 1892 Death place: Council Grove, Morris, Kansas
Comments: In 1832 William enlisted in the Black Hawk War under General Ward. He also enlisted in the Mexican War. In 1845 he sold his farm in Illinois and moved to Clarksville, Missouri. By 1848 he had moved to Keokuk, Lee, Iowa and entered the mercantile business. In 1850 he was a hotel keeper in the community. By 1871 he was in Glenwood, Missouri where he had a mercantile business and was the post officer. In 1879 he moved to Council Grove, Kansas. By 1880 he was a retired dry goods merchant in Adair County, Missouri.
Sources: Ancestry.com; International Genealogical Index; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; United States Federal Census, 1850, 1880.

personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Pelton Given name: Alonzo Birth date: 26 March 1816 Birth place: Chester, Hampden, Massachusetts Father: Pelton, Ezra Mother: Wright, Chloe Spouse: Emeline A. Death date: 21 September 1891
Comments: Alonzo grew up on his father's farm. By 1840 he had entered the mercantile business with his older brothers in Prairie Du Chien, Crawford, Wisconsin. In 1860 he is reported to have been selling soap and candles. He had a real wealth of $15,000.00 and a personal wealth of $10,000.00. By 1867 he was in partnership with a nephew in Freeport, Illinois, selling jewelry, pianos, and organs. They later moved their business to Chicago, Cook, Illinois. He was an LDS Church member for fifty years.
Sources: Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: POWERS, Aaron
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Powers Given name: Aaron Birth date: 1 February 1782 Birth place: New London County, Connecticut Father: Powers, Nicholas Mother: Douglas, Phebe Spouse: Colby, Martha Marriage date: 10 February 1807 Marriage place: North Bend, Hamilton, Ohio Death date: 26 March 1862 Death place: Avon, Warren, Illinois Burial place: Greenbush, Warren, Illinois Comments: Aaron taught school in North Bend, Ohio, for five years. He owned 125 acres in Butler County, Ohio by 1811. In 1839 he bought a farm in Greenbush, Warren, Illinois. There he became a Methodist preacher. He later joined the Mormon Church but soon left it. He then turned to the Missionary Baptist Church and remained with that church until his death. He was left out of is father's will as the family did not know where he was. personk.NAME: RALSTON, James H.
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Ralston Given name: James Middle name: Harvey Birth date: 12 October 1807 Birth place: Bourbon County, Kentucky Father: Ralston, John Mother: Neely, Elizabeth Spouse: Alexander, Jane Marriage date: 11 October 1832 Marriage place: Quincy, Adams, Illinois Spouse: Nancy Marriage date: 2 December 1844 Marriage place: Christian County, Illinois Spouse: Jackson, Harriet N. Marriage date: 20 October 1853 Marriage place: New York City, New York, New York Death date: May 1864 Death place: near San Antonio, Nevada
Comments: On 30 May 1845 James was an assistant to prosecuting attorney Josiah Lamborne in the trial against the nine suspects charged with the murder of the Prophet Joseph Smith and his brother Hyrum. All nine suspects were released. He defended Joseph Smith at a trial in Monmouth. He went to California in 1850 and resided for a time in Sacramento. By 1863 he was a judge in Landers, Nevada. He also served as a state senator.
Sources: Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.CONTENT:

Birth date: about 1797 Birth place: of Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania Spouse: Baum, Sarah Selina Marriage date: 20 January 1820 Marriage place: Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania Death date: 1856 Death place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois
Comments: John was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was a Mormon. In 1850 he was residing in Hancock County, Illinois. According to the Hancock Eagle on Friday, 8 May 1856, Mr. Ray, who lived eight miles from Nauvoo on Pontoosuc Road, was taken from his home and stripped and beaten by a mob. His beating came because he had not sold his property and left the vicinity.

personk.NAME: REDDEN, Return Jackson

Spouse: Murray, Naomi Eliza Marriage date: 16 February 1847 Marriage place: Winter Quarters, Douglas, Nebraska Death date: 30 August 1890 (1891) Death place: Hoytsville, Summit, Utah Comments: Return was a body guard for Joseph Smith. He was endowed on 25 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was in the first pioneer company to reach the Salt Lake Valley. He was among those who laid the overland route from Salt Lake City to California. At the time of his death, he was a member of the 35th Quorum of the Seventies. Sources: 1847 Emigration List; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 470; Esshom, Pioneers and Prominent Men of Utah, p.1123; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 36:218-23; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

He was a missionary to New York in 1844. He was endowed on 19 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. By 1870 he was a farmer in Nicolaus, Sutter, California. personk.NAME: REIMBOLD, Peter
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Reimbold Given name: Peter Birth date: about 1809 Birth place: of Prussia Spouse: Ernestine Death date: 21 June 1861 Death place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois
Comments: Peter came to Nauvoo in 1848. In 1849 he was a doctor in the community. He had horses, cattle, a wagon carriage and other property valued at $175.00. He was the brother of John Reimbold and uncle of Henry I.. Reimbold. He was the father of Max Reimbold, a leading merchant in Nauvoo in 1880. Peter had an office and residence on Main Street near Kimball Street. In 1860 Ernestine was the head of household and a housekeeper in Nauvoo. She had a real wealth of $2,500.00 and a personal wealth of $400.00. It is assumed at that date Peter was dead.
Sources: United States Federal Census, 1860; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

He was in the 11th Quorum of the Seventies. He became a president of the 17th Quorum of Seventies in January 1841.He received a patriarchal blessing on 19 November 1844 in Nauvoo by John Smith. He was endowed on 20 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was captain of the South Company of Riflemen in the September 1846 Battle of Nauvoo. In 1850 he resided in Montecello, Clark, Missouri. By 1860 he was living in Dickerson, Lewis, Missouri. Comments: Benjamin was a quaker. In 1840 he was residing in Chester, Pennsylvania. In April 1846 he migrated to Illinois. He settled in Nauvoo. He rented land near the city of Nauvoo until 1855 when he purchased a farm in Appanoose Township. By 1870 he was a widower in Apanoose, Hancock, Illinois.

Marriage date: 15 February 1885 Marriage place: Iowa Death date: 11 March 1891 Death place: Davis City, Decatur, Iowa Comments: Ebenezer was ordained a seventy in 1836. He was a regent of the University of Nauvoo. He served as a justice of the peace in Nauvoo. He was the editor and publisher of the Times and Seasons. He associated with the Rigdonites in 1844. He affiliated with the RLDS Church in 1863, but by 1888 had united with the Whitmerites. In 1880 he was residing in Decatur, Iowa. personk.NAME: SHERWOOD, Henry G.
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Sherwood Given name: Henry Middle name: Garlic Birth date: 20 April 1785 Birth place: Kingsbury, Washington, New York Father: Sherwood, Newcomb Mother: Tolman Spouse: McManagal, Jane J. Marriage date: about 1824 Marriage place: of Glasgow, Scotland Spouse: Abbott, Marcia Marriage date: about 1835 Marriage place: of Windham, Vermont Death date: 24 November 1862 Death place: San Bernardino, San Bernardino, California Comments: On 22 July 1839 Henry was commanded to come out of his tent and was healed on a bank of the river between the Joseph Smith Homestead and Lowe Stone House. He was called to the high council in October 1839. He was commissioned as a Legion guard on 4 February 1841 and the first city marshal on 3 February 1841. He was endowed on 12 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was authorized to compile a city directory of Nauvoo. He was a surveyor by trade. He was in the first company to leave Nauvoo in 1847. Source: Nauvoo Neighbor, January 24, 1844; United States Federal Census, 1840, p. 181; Temple Committee Ledger, Book C, p. 413; Temple Committee Ledger, Book D, p. 123; Temple Committee Place Book, p. 9; Nauvoo City Treasury, pp. 69, 83; Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 23; Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 232; Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 4:717; United States Federal Census, 1850, 1860; Ancestral File; Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black and Black, Annotated Record of Baptisms for the Dead, 1840-1845, Nauvoo, Hancock County, Illinois, 5:3277-82; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 39:82-85.

He was called as the first city recorder on 3 February 1841. He was elected Church clerk on 2 October 1841. He was a Colonol in the Nauvoo Legion. He became a clerk of the Municipal Court of the City of Nauvoo in March 1843. He was endowed on 22 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was a rifleman in the September 1846 Battle of Nauvoo. He was affiliating with the RLDS Church by 27 August 1876 in California. personk.NAME: THOMPSON, Charles
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Thompson Given name: Charles Middle name: Blanchard Birth date: 27 January 1814 Birth place: Niskayuna, Schenectady, New York Father: Thompson, David Mother: Blancher, Sarah Spouse: Yincks (Jencks), Elizabeth Marriage date: 4 December 1836 Spouse: Houck (Hauck, Hank), Catherine Ann Marriage date: 24 December 1845 Death date: 25 February 1895 Death place: Philadelphia, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Burial place: Philadelphia, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Comments: Charles joined the Church in 1833. In 1839 he served a mission in New York. Following his mission he moved to Nauvoo. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was active in the Church until the death of Joseph Smith. He joined the Strangites. On 1 January 1848 he issued a proclamation saying the Lord would not have a church organization until after the redemption of Zion. He took 50-60 families with him and founded the settlement of Preparation, Iowa. In 1855, after organizing a church there, he was driven from the community by his followers. Sources: United States Federal Census, 1840, p. 214; Nauvoo House Ledger, Book C, p. 304; Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 165; Ancestry.com; Carter, Our Pioneer Heritage; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 43:243-46.

personk.NAME: WALKER, Lorin
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Walker Given name: Lorin Birth date: 25 July 1822 (1823) Birth place: Peacham, Caledonia, Vermont Father: Walker, John Mother: Holmes, Lydia Spouse: Smith, Lavina Marriage date: 23 June 1844 Marriage place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois Spouse: Middlemus (Middleton), Mary Death date: 26 September 1907 Death place: Rockland, Power, Idaho Burial place: Rockland, Power, Idaho Comments: Lorin and Lavina were married by Aaron Johnson. Lorin was the son-in-law of Hyrum Smith and was the keeper of the Nauvoo Temple. He was a member of the 14th Quorum of the Seventy. He was endowed on 30 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. In 1848 he left Nauvoo and went to McDonough County to assist in opening coal banks where the village of Colchester now stands. Sources: David D. Yearsley Ledger, p. 82; Reimbold Scrapbook, 1890; Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 56 (January 1842-April 1844); Temple Committee Carpenter Time, Book C; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 44:555-58; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index.

Spouse: Davis, Lydia Marriage date: 15 October 1852 Spouse: Davis, Hannah Marriage date: 15 October 1853 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Spouse: Davis, Martha Marriage date: 15 October 1854 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Death date: 30 January 1900 Death place: Granger, Salt Lake, Utah Burial date: 4 February 1900 Burial place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: In 1842 George was in the lumber business in Boston. He was converted to the gospel by Joseph Smith. He was an undertaker by trade and followed that occupation from Nauvoo in 1844 to the Salt Lake Valley. He was the first sexton to dig a civilized grave in the Salt Lake Valley. He served as President of the Salt Lake Stake from 1874-1876. Sources: "Letters of a Proselyte," Utah Historical Quarterly, vol. 25, p. 238; Temple Committee Carpenter Time, Book C; Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 1:291; Ancestral File; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 44:630-37.

personk.NAME: WANDELL, Charles Wesley
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Male Surname: Wandell Given name: Charles Middle name: Wesley Birth date: 12 April 1819 Birth place: Courtland, Westchester, New York Father: Wandell, Jacob Mother: Haight, Mariam Spouse: Brown (Pratt), Mary Marriage date: 21 January 1846 Spouse: Hamilton, Mary Holland Marriage date: 30 November 1859 Marriage place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Death date: 14 March 1875 Death place: Sydney, Australia Comments: Charles was baptized in 1837 in New York. He was a clerk in Willard Richard's office. In 1844 he was a steamboat officer in St. Louis, Missouri. He was ordained a seventy and endowed on 3 January 1846 in the Nauvoo Temple. He was the first LDS missionary to serve in Australia from 1852-1853. In 1873 he joined the "Josephites." He later served an RLDS mission to Australia, where he took sick and died. Sources: Temple Committee Ledger, Book C, p. 207; Jenson, LDS Biographical Encyclopedia, 3:551; Ancestral File; Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.; Black, Membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1830-1848, 44:727-30; Black, Nauvoo Seventy Membership: Annotated Index; Black, Early Members of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, 6:91.

personk.NAME: WARREN, Calvin A.
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Warren Given name: Calvin Middle name: A. Birth date: about 1807 Birth place: of New York Spouse: Robbins, Harriet Wheeler Marriage date: 30 August 1849 Marriage place: Adams County, Illinois Spouse: Wady, Ann Death date: 22 February 1881 Death place: Quincy, Adams, Illinois
Comments: Calvin was primarily an attorney by trade. He was educated at the Transylvania Law University. He was also a printer, editor, and a Presbyterian. He was hired to represent the nine suspects in the murder trial of the Prophet Joseph Smith. All nine were acquitted for the murder. In 1850 he was a lawyer in Adams County, Illinois. He had a real wealth of $10,000.00.
Sources: "This Week in Church History: Trial Travesty Frees Carthage Mobsters," Deseret News, week ending 5 June 1965; United States Federal Census, 1840, 1850, 1870; Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: WELD, John Fuller
personk.CONTENT:
Gender: Male Surname: Weld Given name: John Middle name: Fuller Birth date: about 1809 Spouse: Hibbard, Emeline Marriage date: 4 July 1845 Marriage place: Hancock County, Illinois Spouse: Collins, Ruth Elizabeth Marriage date: 7 April 1855 Marriage place: Hancock County, Illinois Death date: 28 July 1892 Death place: Nauvoo, Hancock, Illinois
Comments: John became a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion in March 1841. He amputed the leg of William Yokum on 25 July 1841. He was a merchant by trade and owned a store and office on Mullholland Street, where he sold drugs and medicines. He was still in Navuoo in 1859. From 1850 to 1880 he was a resident of Hancock County, Illinois. During most of those years he was a physician.
Sources: Hancock County Taxes, 1842, p. 226; United States Federal Census, 1850, 1870, 1890; Ancestry.com; Rowena Miller Files, Lands and Records Office, Nauvoo Restoration, Inc.

personk.NAME: WELLS, Daniel Hanmer
personk.CONTENT: Gender: Wells Surname: Daniel Given name: Hanmer Birth date: 27 October 1814 Birth place: Trenton, Oneida, New York Father: Wells, Daniel Mother: Chapin, Catherine (Cathrine) Spouse: Robison (Robinson), Eliza R. Marriage date: 1835 (12 March 1837) Marriage place: Commerce, Hancock, Illinois Death date: 24 March 1891 Death place: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake, Utah Comments: Daniel became an alderman on 1 February 1841 and the first University regent on 3 February 1841. He participated as an aid-de-camp in the September 1846 Battle of Nauvoo. The Prophet Joseph Smith stopped by his home en route to Carthage, Hancock, Illinois in 1844. He served in the First Presidency with Brigham Young. Sources: Temple Committee Ledger, Book A, p. 60; Temple Committee Ledger, Book D, p. 402; Joseph Smith Ledger, Book A, p. 104 (April 1842-October 1842); Nauvoo City Treasury, p. 87; Roberts, Rise and Fall of Nauvoo, p. 296; David D. He arrived in Commerce in 1840. He resided in the Nauvoo 1st Ward. He was a soldier in the Nauvoo Legion. He was a merchant by trade. He was endowed on 22 December 1845 in the Nauvoo Temple. He had 8 children with his first wife Mary. They had children in Nauvoo in 1840, 1843, and 1845. He and his first three wives left Nauvoo on 5 June 1846.
